[Synopsis]==================================                                                                

  My Life to Live [Vivre sa vie] | France | 1962 | Directed by Jean-Luc Godard
                                  
Godard's poetic treatment of one womanÃƒÂ«Ã‚Â­Ã‚Â© slide into the oldest profession in the 
world stars his then-wife (and muse), the enigmatically lovely Anna Karina. The 
film opens with a quote by Montaigne: ÃƒÂ«Ã‚Â°Ã…Â¡end yourself to others, but give yourself 
to yourself.?Told in 12 sections, the film charts the attempt by Nana (Karina) to 
do just that. Nana leaves her husband and child with a vague notion of becoming an 
actress. In one of the filmÃƒÂ«Ã‚Â­Ã‚Â© most remarkable moments, Raoul CoutardÃƒÂ«Ã‚Â­Ã‚Â© lustrous 
black-and-white camera captures KarinaÃƒÂ«Ã‚Â­Ã‚Â© rapt, tear-stained identification with 
Maria Falconetti's transcendent performance in Carl DreyerÃƒÂ«Ã‚Â­Ã‚Â© The Passion of Joan 
of Arc. But Nana drifts into prostitution instead. GodardÃƒÂ«Ã‚Â­Ã‚Â© treatment of the theme 
is almost case-study objective, but he manages something very intimate and heartfelt 
here. ÃƒÂ«Ã‚Â°Ã‚Â«he camera by its discipline discourages us from interpreting NanaÃƒÂ«Ã‚Â­Ã‚Â© life in 
a melodramatic way. Curious, then, how moving Anna Karina makes Nana. She waits, 
she drinks, she smokes, she walks the streets, she makes some money, she turns 
herself over to the first pimp she meets, she gives up control of her life. The 
effect is astonishing. It is clear, astringent, unsentimental, and abrupt. Then it 
is over. It was her life to live.
